subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] The Seven - interesting tidbit of info
author: April Abercrombie
full_text:
------=_NextPart_000_0032_01C9D208.C7A265D0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

That would make sense as a death reference as well. Someone's out-of-servic=
e......permanently LOL!

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Rj 
  To: =
EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Monday, May 11, 2009 7:08 AM
  Subject: Re=
: [EVP-ITC] The Seven - interesting tidbit of info






        Code 7 is =
either code for being out of service (short for 10-7), or a meal break:

  =
      http://www.radiolabs.com/police-codes.html
        http://www.yougeti=
nfo.com/info/PolCodes.html


        --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulle=
tbabea@...> wrote:


          From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@...=
m>
          Subject: [EVP-ITC] The Seven - interesting tidbit of info
    =
      To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
          Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 9:3=
1 PM


                Tonight at work I was talking to a state trooper, th=
ere had been an accident. I asked him if there were any deaths (it was very=
 very bad) and he said he didnt know so he got on his radio and called in a=
nd asked them if it was a 7 at the site. They told him negative, and he tol=
d me the little boy who was the worst off was still alive. I asked him why =
did you ask them if it was a 7. He said code 7, I was asking them if they w=
ere dead. So if you ever hear anyone call 7 over the radio that means someo=
nes dead.

                Just thought I would pass that on. I find it int=
eresting since I know alot of us have heard this before when used to descri=
be who is speaking rather than a name they say seven.

                Mist=
y
